1. **Semantic model**: What confidence represents, how defeaters affect it

- Theoretical analysis (Alice)

- User studies / literature review on presentation formats (Charlie)

Prototype follows validated specification.

This research supports the TEA platform (https://assuranceplatform.azurewebsites.net/docs/about) automation roadmap, specifically the planned Analysis Plugin architecture for confidence assessment.

## Overview
A set of React components that render rich, interactive previews of agent-created artifacts in the chat UI. When the frontend encounters an artifact message (from the artifact_share tool), it renders the appropriate viewer based on file type.

An `<ArtifactViewer project={...} path={...} />` component that:

- Detects file type from extension/MIME type
- Delegates to the appropriate format-specific renderer

| Format | Renderer | Package |
|--------|----------|---------|
| Code/text | Syntax-highlighted read-only view | Shiki |
| Markdown | Rendered markdown | react-markdown (or existing renderer) |
| PDF | Page-by-page viewer | react-pdf |
| HTML | Sandboxed preview | iframe with sandbox attribute |
| Images | Responsive image display | Next.js Image or native img |

## UI Design
- Renders inline in conversation as a card/panel (not a separate page)
- Shows file name, title (if provided), and agent's message
- Download button linking to the file download endpoint

- artifact_share message schema (team-x03)

title: Sidebar overhaul: dynamic DMs, collapsible sections, and channel consolidation
description:
## Overview

The sidebar needs a significant overhaul to support dynamically created agents and channels, with collapsible sections and proper CRUD workflows. Currently, DMs are hardcoded to 3 system agents (alice/bob/charlie) in `AGENTS` constant, channels can't be managed inline, and the sidebar doesn't scale well as lists grow.

## Current State

### DMs (`nav-dms.tsx`)
- **Hardcoded** to `AGENTS` constant (alice, bob, charlie) — no way to DM user-created agents
- Online status and unread counts work for the 3 system agents
- No add/remove DM capability

### Channels (`nav-channels.tsx`)
- **Dynamic** — fetched from `/api/backend/channels` via SWR
- Has "Create Channel" (+) button and settings gear icon per non-system channel
- `ChannelManageDialog` supports adding/removing agents and users, ownership transfer, delete
- **Bug (original 18b):** `#team` channel only exists in JSONL system, not SQLite — doesn't appear in sidebar

### Sidebar (`app-sidebar.tsx`)
- Three flat sections: Channels, DMs, nav links (Monitoring, Agents, Admin)
- **Not collapsible** — no way to collapse sections when lists grow long
- No collapsible UI component exists yet (need to add shadcn `Collapsible`)

### Agent System
- System agents: `alice`, `bob`, `charlie` (hardcoded in `constants.ts`, `is_system: true`)
- User agents: created via Agents page, stored as `.claude/agents/{name}.md` with `owner` field
- `getAgent()` already has a fallback for unknown IDs — returns generated defaults
- Backend already supports listing all agents via `GET /api/agents`

## Requirements

### 1. Consolidate #team channel into SQLite (original 18b)
- Ensure `#team` has a row in the `channels` table with `owner_id='system'`
- Either seed it on server startup or migrate it
- After this, #team appears in the sidebar like any other channel

### 2. Dynamic DMs — fetch agents from API
- Replace the hardcoded `AGENTS` constant in `nav-dms.tsx` with a fetch to `/api/agents` (or a new endpoint)
- Show **only user-owned agents** (non-system) in the DM list — system agents (alice/bob/charlie) are always shown
- When a user creates a new agent on the Agents page, it should immediately appear in the DM sidebar
- The DM page (`/dm/[agent]`) already works for any agent ID via `getAgent()` fallback — just needs the sidebar entry
- Online status and unread counts should work for dynamic agents too

### 3. Channel CRUD from sidebar
- Channel creation already works (+ button → `/channels/new`)
- Channel settings already work (gear icon → `ChannelManageDialog`)
- Channel deletion is inside `ChannelManageDialog` — this is sufficient
- **Ensure**: users can only delete channels they own; system channels are not deletable (already enforced)

### 4. Collapsible sidebar sections
- Add shadcn `Collapsible` component (`npx shadcn@latest add collapsible`)
- Wrap both "Channels" and "Direct Messages" `SidebarGroup` sections with collapsible behavior
- Clicking the section header (label) toggles collapse/expand
- Default to expanded; persist collapse state in localStorage
- Use chevron icon to indicate expand/collapse state

## Key Files

| File | Change |
|------|--------|
| `team-dashboard/src/components/sidebar/nav-dms.tsx` | Replace hardcoded AGENTS with API fetch; show user agents |
| `team-dashboard/src/components/sidebar/nav-channels.tsx` | Wrap in Collapsible |
| `team-dashboard/src/components/sidebar/app-sidebar.tsx` | Adjust layout for collapsible sections |
| `team-dashboard/src/lib/constants.ts` | Keep AGENTS for system agent styling; add agent type |
| `team-dashboard/src/components/ui/collapsible.tsx` | Add shadcn collapsible component |
| `team-server/src/index.ts` | Seed #team channel on startup; possibly new endpoint for DM-eligible agents |
| `team-server/src/db.ts` | Seed logic for system channels |

## Out of Scope
- Agent creation/editing from sidebar (use Agents page)
- Channel creation inline (keep existing /channels/new page flow)
- DMs between human users (only user→agent DMs)

title: Build team chat PWA with Discord-style UI
description:
## Summary

Replace Slack with a custom PWA for agent communication. Discord-style UI with channels and DMs.

## Tech Stack

- Next.js + React
- shadcn/ui + Tailwind
- [sidebar-07](https://ui.shadcn.com/blocks/sidebar) for navigation
- [Assistant UI](https://www.shadcn.io/template/assistant-ui-assistant-ui) for chat components
- WebSocket connection to team-server

## UI Structure

```
┌─────────────┬──────────────────────────┐
│ Sidebar     │ Chat Area                │
│             │                          │
│ CHANNELS    │ #team                    │
│ #team       │ ────────────────────     │
│ #research   │ Alice: I think...        │
│             │ Bob: Agreed, but...      │
│ DMs         │ Charlie: From my POV...  │
│ @alice      │                          │
│ @bob        │                          │
│ @charlie    │ [Input box]              │
└─────────────┴──────────────────────────┘
```

## Features

- Distinct avatar/color per agent
- Real-time updates via WebSocket
- Typing indicators
- Message timestamps
- Channel switching
- 1:1 DM with each agent
- Mobile responsive

## Backend (existing)

- team-server REST API
- WebSocket at ws://localhost:3030/ws
- SQLite storage

## Auth

- Simple token-based auth initially
- Can add OAuth later
notes:
## Security Requirements

### Authentication
- NextAuth with Credentials provider
- Single user (username/password)
- HTTP-only cookie sessions
- Strong password requirement

### Bot Protection
- Rate limiting on login (5 attempts/min)
- Non-obvious auth paths
- CORS restricted to app domain

### Future Considerations
- IP allowlist (once stable device set known)
- TOTP 2FA

## Agent Permissions

Use `permissionMode: dontAsk` with explicit `allowedTools` whitelist per agent. No permission prompts - denied tools fail gracefully.

## Slash Commands

PWA supports slash commands to trigger different agent behaviors.

### `/update` - Independent parallel
- Triggers alice, bob, charlie simultaneously
- Each posts update independently
- No coordination needed

### `/discuss <topic>` - Sequential with orchestrator
- Orchestrator agent (sonnet) facilitates
- Loop: Alice → Bob → Charlie → Orchestrator decision
- Orchestrator decides: another round or consensus reached
- Continues until task complete

### Future commands
- TBD based on usage patterns

## Orchestrator Agent

- 4th agent, facilitator role
- Model: sonnet (needs reasoning)
- Doesn't do tasks, manages flow
- Decides consensus/completion

## Agent-to-Agent Delegation

Agents can request help from other agents while preserving memory.

### MCP Tool: `mcp__team__request_help`

```typescript
request_help({
  agent: "alice",
  task: "Analyze epistemological framing",
  context: "Working on X, need your expertise on Y"
})
```

**Flow:**
1. Charlie calls `request_help(agent="alice", ...)`
2. MCP server stores request in team.db
3. Triggers Alice's session (with her session-id)
4. Alice sees request, does work, stores response
5. Response returned to Charlie

**Benefits:**
- Alice's memory persists
- Charlie gets result
- Both sessions maintain history
- No infinite loops (request has task scope)

## Real-time Agent Status via Hooks

Hooks POST to team-server, broadcast via WebSocket to PWA.

### Hooks Used

| Hook | Event | Status |
|------|-------|--------|
| `PreToolUse` | tool_start | "Using Edit on file.ts" |
| `PostToolUse` | tool_complete | "Completed Edit" |
| `PostToolUseFailure` | tool_error | "Failed: Edit" |
| `Stop` | agent_idle | "Finished" |
| `Notification` | notification | Permission needs, idle, etc. |

### Endpoint

POST `/api/agent/status`:
```json
{
  "agent": "alice",
  "event": "tool_start",
  "tool": "Edit", 
  "detail": "editing src/file.ts",
  "timestamp": "..."
}
```

### PWA Display
- Real-time status per agent
- Tool currently in use
- Error/failure notifications
- Idle/active indicators

## Notifications

Slack-style notification system.

### Badge Counts
- Unread message count per channel/DM
- Visual indicator on sidebar
- Clear on view

### Browser Notifications
- Optional push notifications for new messages
- Configurable per channel

### In-App Alerts
- Toast notifications for important events
- Agent errors/failures
- Task completions

title: Orchestrator should DM agents to dispatch work instead of relying on @mentions
description:
## Problem

When the orchestrator decomposes a task, it creates beads issues and posts a summary to a channel, but never actually triggers agents to start working. Agents are not informed of their assignments.

## Root Cause

The orchestrator skill creates issues and posts @mentions in channel messages, but:
1. MCP channel_write does not trigger agents for @mentions (only the HTTP path does)
2. Even if it did, the orchestrator doesn't reliably format @mentions

## Solution

Rather than fixing @mention detection in the MCP path (fragile), the orchestrator should explicitly DM each assigned agent via message_send to dispatch work. This uses the existing reliable DM trigger path.

### New orchestrator dispatch flow:

1. Create epic + subtask issues in beads
2. For each unblocked subtask with an assignee, send a DM via message_send:
   - To: the assigned agent (e.g. "alice")
   - Content: instruction to work on the issue (e.g. "You have been assigned team-xyz: <title>. Run /plan-issue team-xyz to begin. Post findings to #<channel>. When complete, close the issue with bd close and message me back.")
3. Each agent gets triggered via the existing DM dispatch path (polling detects unread → triggerAgent)
4. Agents work, close their issue, DM the orchestrator when done
5. Orchestrator gets triggered by reply DMs, can check progress and advance blocked work

### Changes required:

- Update .claude/commands/orchestrate:decompose.md — Step 5 ("Trigger First Wave") should use message_send to DM each agent instead of @mentioning in a channel post
- Update dispatcher.ts orchestrator prompt — reinforce that agents must be dispatched via message_send, not @mentions
- Optionally update orchestrate:status.md — when advancing newly-unblocked work, also DM the assigned agents

## Files

- .claude/commands/orchestrate:decompose.md — decomposition skill Step 5
- .agents/identities/orchestrator.md — orchestrator communication patterns
- team-server/src/dispatcher.ts — orchestrator prompt construction (~line 1001)

title: Agents DM orchestrator with status updates that clutter their DM history
description:
## Problem

When agents complete orchestrated tasks, they DM the orchestrator with status updates (e.g. 'Done — posted to #2n1-test. Closed team-c8s.'). These DMs appear in the agent's DM view from the user's perspective, making the DM history confusing — the user sees messages like 'Done — posted to #2n1-test' with no context about what task this refers to.

## Observed

Alice's DM view shows:
- 'Done — posted top 3 explainability techniques to #2n1-test. Closed team-qnt.'
- 'Done — posted to #2n1-test. Closed team-c8s.'

These are agent→orchestrator DMs that the user shouldn't need to see in their DM view with Alice.

## Root Cause

The DM system shows all messages to/from an agent in a single view. When Alice sends a message_send to the orchestrator, it appears in Alice's DM history. The user's DM view with Alice mixes user↔alice messages with orchestrator↔alice messages.

## Possible Fixes

1. Filter DM views to only show messages involving the current user (not agent↔agent DMs)
2. Show agent↔agent DMs in a separate section or with a visual distinction
3. Have the orchestrator use a different communication channel for status updates (not DMs visible to users)

title: Session management (channel + DM scoping)
description:
## Overview
Implement session isolation: channel-scoped sessions for shared context, user+project-scoped for DMs.

## Validated Approach
Tested: Claude CLI supports `--session-id <uuid>` to create sessions with predetermined IDs, and `-r <uuid>` to resume them.

```bash
# Create with known ID
claude --session-id 11111111-2222-3333-4444-555555555555 -p "Hello"

# Resume later
claude -r 11111111-2222-3333-4444-555555555555 -p "What did we discuss?"
```

## Session Model
- **Channel**: One Claude session per agent per channel (shared by all channel members)
- **DM**: One Claude session per user+project+agent (private)

## Implementation

### Session Registry (SQLite)
```sql
CREATE TABLE sessions (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  type TEXT NOT NULL,           -- 'channel' | 'dm'
  user_id TEXT,                 -- for DMs (null for channels)
  channel_id TEXT,              -- for channels (null for DMs)
  project_path TEXT NOT NULL,
  agent_id TEXT NOT NULL,
  session_id TEXT NOT NULL,     -- UUID we generate
  created_at DATETIME DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
  UNIQUE(type, user_id, channel_id, project_path, agent_id)
);
```

### Dispatcher Changes
```typescript
function getOrCreateSession(context: {
  type: 'channel' | 'dm'
  userId?: string
  channelId?: string
  projectPath: string
  agentId: string
}): string {
  const existing = db.sessions.find({ ...context })
  if (existing) return existing.sessionId
  
  const sessionId = crypto.randomUUID()
  db.sessions.insert({ ...context, sessionId })
  return sessionId
}

// In dispatch:
const sessionId = getOrCreateSession({ type: 'dm', userId, projectPath, agentId })
spawn('claude', ['--session-id', sessionId, prompt, '-p'])
```

## Depends On
- Multi-user auth (need user_id for DM scoping)

title: Dispatcher doesn't detect stale agent processes that completed but never exited
description:
## Problem

When the dispatcher spawns a Claude CLI session via Bun.spawn(), it relies on `proc.exited` (a promise) to detect completion. However, the Claude CLI process sometimes completes its work but never actually exits — it hangs at 0% CPU indefinitely.

This leaves the dispatcher thinking the agent is still active, blocking any new work from being dispatched to that agent.

## Observed

- Orchestrator PID 44266 ran for 33+ minutes at 0% CPU after completing its decomposition task
- `proc.exited` promise never resolved, so `onComplete` was never called
- Dispatcher reported `active: true` with `activeForMs: null` and `lastExitCode: 0` (stale from previous run)
- Could not refresh or re-trigger the orchestrator: 'has an active session — cannot refresh while running'

## Root Cause

The Claude CLI with `-p` flag sometimes hangs after completing work, possibly waiting for MCP server cleanup or stdio drain. The dispatcher has no timeout or watchdog to detect this.

## Suggested Fix

Add a watchdog/timeout mechanism to spawnClaudeSession():
1. Track when the last stdout/stderr output was received
2. If no output for N minutes (e.g. 5min) and the process is still running, consider it stale
3. Send SIGTERM, wait briefly, then SIGKILL if needed
4. Call onComplete with a special exit code indicating timeout

Alternatively or additionally:
- Add a max session duration (e.g. 10min) after which the process is killed
- The existing stale process reaping in dispatcher.ts may need to cover this case

## Files

- team-server/src/dispatcher.ts — spawnClaudeSession() (lines 75-238), stale process detection

title: Integrate Zotero MCP server for research library access
description:
## Summary

Integrate the Zotero MCP server (https://github.com/54yyyu/zotero-mcp) to give research agents access to a shared Zotero reference library. This enables Alice, Bob, Charlie, and Demi to search, retrieve, and annotate research papers directly from Zotero within their workflows.

## Background

Zotero MCP provides tools for searching a Zotero library (keyword + semantic search), retrieving full-text content, accessing PDF annotations, and managing notes. It supports both the local Zotero API (requires Zotero 7+ running) and the Zotero Web API.

Prerequisites: Python 3.10+, Zotero 7+ (for local mode)

## Steps

### 1. Install and configure the MCP server

Install via uv:
\`\`\`bash
uv tool install "git+https://github.com/54yyyu/zotero-mcp.git"
zotero-mcp setup
\`\`\`

Add to MCP configuration:
\`\`\`json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "zotero": {
      "command": "zotero-mcp",
      "env": {
        "ZOTERO_LOCAL": "true"
      }
    }
  }
}
\`\`\`

Decide on connection mode:
- **Local API** (\`ZOTERO_LOCAL=true\`): Requires Zotero 7+ running on the host. Provides full-text access.
- **Web API** (\`ZOTERO_API_KEY\`, \`ZOTERO_LIBRARY_ID\`): Works without a local Zotero instance but may have limitations.

Optionally configure semantic search (embedding model for similarity-based queries):
\`\`\`bash
zotero-mcp setup --semantic-config-only
zotero-mcp update-db --fulltext
\`\`\`

### 2. Configure permissions in settings

Add the Zotero MCP tools to the allowed permissions in \`settings.local.json\` (or \`settings.json\`). The server exposes many tools—key ones to allow:
- \`zotero_search_items\`, \`zotero_advanced_search\`, \`zotero_semantic_search\`
- \`zotero_get_item_metadata\`, \`zotero_get_item_fulltext\`
- \`zotero_get_annotations\`, \`zotero_get_notes\`, \`zotero_create_note\`
- \`zotero_get_collections\`, \`zotero_get_tags\`, \`zotero_get_recent\`

Ensure agents can use these tools without interactive prompts.

### 3. Update agent system prompts (Alice, Bob, Charlie, Demi)

Update the identity/system prompt files for all four agents in \`.agents/identities/\` so they know:
- The Zotero MCP server is available for searching and retrieving research papers
- They can search by keyword, tags, or semantic similarity
- They can retrieve full text, metadata, BibTeX citations, and PDF annotations
- Notes can be created on items to capture research insights
- Retrieved content can be saved to the shared \`research-sources/\` directory

### 4. Verify integration

- Confirm the server starts and connects to Zotero successfully
- Test a search query and full-text retrieval
- If using semantic search, verify the embedding database is populated (\`zotero-mcp db-status\`)

## Available Tools (Reference)

| Category | Tools |
|----------|-------|
| Search | \`zotero_search_items\`, \`zotero_advanced_search\`, \`zotero_semantic_search\` |
| Browse | \`zotero_get_collections\`, \`zotero_get_tags\`, \`zotero_get_recent\`, \`zotero_search_by_tag\` |
| Content | \`zotero_get_item_metadata\`, \`zotero_get_item_fulltext\`, \`zotero_get_item_children\` |
| Annotations | \`zotero_get_annotations\`, \`zotero_get_notes\`, \`zotero_search_notes\`, \`zotero_create_note\` |
| Semantic DB | \`zotero_update_search_database\`, \`zotero_get_search_database_status\` |

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Zotero MCP server is installed and configured
- [ ] Connection mode chosen and documented (local vs web API)

- [ ] All four agents (Alice, Bob, Charlie, Demi) have updated prompts referencing the capability

title: Typing indicator shows wrong agent in DM views
description:
## Problem

When viewing Alice's DMs, typing indicators for other agents (Orchestrator, Charlie) appear at the bottom of the conversation. These agents are not part of this DM conversation — their typing activity is from other contexts (channels, other DMs).

## Observed

In Alice's DM view:
- 'Orchestrator typing...' indicator appeared
- 'Charlie typing...' indicator appeared
- Neither agent is part of the Alice DM conversation

## Root Cause

The typing indicator component likely subscribes to all WebSocket typing events globally and displays any active agent's typing state, regardless of which conversation the user is viewing. It needs to be scoped to the current conversation context.

## Fix

The typing indicator needs a rethink for the current architecture (multiple channels, multiple agents, DMs):
1. Typing events should include context (which channel or DM conversation the agent is typing in)
2. The typing indicator component should filter to only show typing for the current view
3. In a DM view with Alice, only show Alice's typing indicator
4. In a channel view, only show typing indicators for agents active in that channel

## Files

- team-dashboard/src/components/chat/ — typing indicator component
- team-server/src/index.ts — WebSocket typing event broadcasting
close_reason: Typing indicator now scoped to current conversation: in DM views only shows the current agent, in channel views shows all active agents.
